subtitle: The inaugural issue of the New Thinking Allowed

You can even order a printed copy from nta-magazine.magcloud.com.

Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today, we are going to look at the human kingdom and the animal kingdom.
We're going to see what distinguishes them and what do they have in common.
With me is Miranda Alcott.
She is an intuitive animal communicator.
She is also the author of a chapter called
Listening to Water in a book titled The Healing
Properties of Water edited by Masaru Imoto.
Welcome, Miranda.
Thank you, Jeffrey.
Thank you for asking me to come.
Pleasure to be with you once again.
I'm of mixed minds about this question and I say so and I'll just lay it out.
One of my mentors was the cosmologist Arthur M. Young.
He had a very detailed cosmology in which he
maintained the human kingdom of which biological
humans such as ourselves represent a tiny part.
I think he would say it included angels and maybe deities.
But the human kingdom, he saw it as distinct
from the animal kingdom even though we are
animals.
Just in the same way, I think that animals are distinct from the plant kingdom.
He would say in the mineral kingdom, you have
minerals, plants, animals, humans, all distinct
kingdoms.
On the other hand, there are writers like Desmond Morris, the author of The Naked Ape
in which he says, you know, there's hardly anything that really distinguishes us from
animals.
We're so much like animals.
Well, we are.
I think we do ourselves a disservice when we
feel we have to distinguish ourselves from
the rest of the animal kingdoms and the plant kingdom.
I understand the lore and the appreciation of the plant kingdom.
But I think we do a big disservice to the plant people and to ourselves when we think
that we are separate from.
Plant people.
Yes.
To me, they're people.
Someone said to me the other day, Randy, you know the difference between you and me?
And I said, well, no.
And she said to me, because to you, everything talks, and it truly does.
And I think that if we hold the perspective,
at least the possibility of it, that people
will understand they're hearing and experiencing a lot more.

as silence and it's not?
What is it that we feel?
What is it that we sense?
And people say they're rocks, for Pete's sake.
They're stones and they're beings, and they carry a lot of information.
Just as we know plants.
And they're those wonderful people who are making music, attaching diodes to plants.

every time we say we are separate from, we

No, we have a different form of intelligence.

That's really great, but if you don't really

to say, yeah, but my cat doesn't drive my car.
No, that's correct, and your cat didn't mess up the environment either.
Humans seem to be the only species who have
the capacity to destroy all life on the planet.
That's a really great point.
I have no argument for that.
That's absolutely true.
And it's because of the fact that we make tools.
I know other animals use tools.
Many of them, crows being one, make their own tools.
We can't really hide behind the fact that it's because we make tools.
It's how far we've taken it with this intelligence that we have.
With this intelligence that we have, we've messed up a lot.

Well, undoing what we've done seems to be one of our weaknesses.

We seem to have the capacity to imagine something

either to believe that it's real, like a work
